The Monty Tech Fall Reopening Plan is now available!

After reviewing a great deal of information, a careful review of building capacity vs. state guidance documents, and a consistent focus on "what is best for our students", we have determined that we will reopen under a Hybrid Learning Plan.

Essentially, only half of the students will be in the building at any given time - and we have tried to balance vocational and academic instruction, by coming up with a 3/2 model- that's 3 days of in-person vocational instruction and 2 days of in-person academic instruction in each two week cycle. The schedule is detailed and thoughtful - and you are encouraged to review the plan in its entirety at:
https://www.montytech.net/cms/lib/MA02212741/Centricity/Domain/4242/FINAL%20Monty%20Tech%20Fall%20Reopening%20Plan.pdf

After months of renovating space, purchasing and installing new equipment and technology, and writing new curriculum, a $500,000 improvement to the Monty Tech Electrical, Engineering and CAD Drafting & Design programs is now complete. Thanks to the Massachusetts Skills Capital Grant Program, these students will work and learn in state-of-the-art laboratories, gaining skills in automation, robotics, mechatronics and fabrication.

The ARM Lab features automation technology that will allow students to learn a variety of programmable logic control systems, expanding their skills set to include management, programming, and diagnostics of critical electromechanical applications.

Training tools include robotic arms, conveyor systems, traffic light systems, bottling processes and variable frequency drives, which will provide students with a deep understanding of the importance of speed and quality in manufacturing and electrical control processes. Students will also learn how large distributors use automation to place, pull, package, and ship goods to consumers.

We couldn't be prouder of Kira Andreucci, 17, a junior at Montachusett Regional Vocational Technical School, who provides backpacks filled with food to more than 225 children every Friday during the school year to keep them from going hungry over the weekend.

When Kira was in the fifth grade, she saw a child taking food out of a recycling bin at her school. This touched something deep in Kira, who was adopted from China by her American family when she was 17 months old and who, her parents believe, often went hungry during the early months of her life. She and her father did some research and learned that one in five children go to bed hungry. "I wanted to do something to help children who are less fortunate than me," said Kira.

Please help us congratulate Kira, who recently traveled to Washington, D.C., where she was recognized at the Prudential Spirit of Community Awards program, and named Massachusetts' top high school volunteer!

To hear more from Kira, please visit: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aBaeJqCwxMY&feature=youtu.be
